title: Four eclectic renovations by General Assembly: Your Next Employer?
author: Niall Patrick Walsh
excerpt: Following our previous visit to JFAK, we are moving our Meet Your Next Employer series to New York City this week to explore the work of General Assembly. A boutique, full-service design office led by Sarah Zames and Colin Stief, the firm specializes in homes
text: Following our previous visit to JFAK, we are moving our Meet Your Next Employer series to New York City this week to explore the work of General Assembly. A boutique, full-service design office led by Sarah Zames and Colin Stief, the firm specializes in homes "rooted in the spaces and narratives of its clients.” The firm describes its work as one that champions “craft, foreground honest materials, heirloom-quality objects meant to improve with time and enhance everyday life.” Over on Archinect Jobs, the firm is currently hiring for a Senior Interior Architect to join their Brooklyn team. For candidates interested in applying for a position or anybody interested in learning more about the firm’s output, we have rounded up four renovation projects by General Assembly that exemplify the firm’s ethos. Key West Vacation Home. Image credit: William Jess LairdKey West Vacation Home, Key West, FL General Assembly redesigned the interior of a 1970s vacation home in Key West, Florida, for a New York-based family. The project balances the home’s clean architectural lines with warmer materials, patterned tiles, and colorful textiles. Influences include the Ernest Hemingway House, 1980s Florida aesthetics, vintage advertising, and the owners’ wood-paneled Chrysler LeBaron.  Learn more on the Key West Vacation Home's Archinect project page Key West Vacation Home. Image credit: William Jess LairdKey West Vacation Home. Image credit: William Jess LairdCatskills Farm, Stone Ridge, NY For the Catskills Farm project, General Assembly converted an old horse barn into a guest house, retaining elements of the original structure. Warm wood cladding contrasts with clean white walls to create a balanced interior. Patterned concrete tiles define distinct areas: custom terracotta tiles surround the wood-burning stove, while black and white tiles distinguish the bedrooms, which also feature in-floor heating. Learn more on the Catskills Farm's Archinect project page Catskills Farm. Image credit: Joe FletcherCatskills Farm. Image credit: Joe FletcherCallicoon Stone House, Callicoon, NY The Callicoon Stone House project saw General Assembly renovate a 19th-century stone house originally built in 1780. The design preserved the original stone structure while reorganizing the interior to improve functionality. Existing window openings were maintained, with two converted into exterior doors to frame key views. New elements, including walls and lighting, were inserted within the original stone shell, creating a clear contrast between old and new. Learn more on the Callicoon Stone House's Archinect project page Callicoon Stone House. Image credit: Matthew Williams PhotographyCallicoon Stone House. Image credit: Matthew Williams PhotographyBleeker Street, New York, NY General Assembly renovated a 1,200-square-foot apartment on Bleecker Street in Manhattan’s West Village, merging a one-bedroom unit with an adjoining studio. The design draws inspiration from a Cubist painting, using rich materials such as velvet, patinated brass, and dark wood to create a warm, nostalgic atmosphere. Crisp detailing and millwork provide contrast and structure, while heirlooms and artworks, including a drawing by Andy Warhol, add historical depth. Learn more on Bleeker Street's Archinect project page Bleeker Street. Image credit: William Jess LairdBleeker Street. Image credit: William Jess LairdMeet Your Next Employer is one of a number of ongoing weekly series showcasing the opportunities available on our industry-leading job board. Our Job Highlights series looks at intriguing and topical employment opportunities currently available on Archinect Jobs, while our weekly roundups curate job opportunities by location, career level, and job description.
html:
Following our previous visit to JFAK, we are moving our Meet Your Next Employer series to New York City this week to explore the work of General Assembly.

A boutique, full-service design office led by Sarah Zames and Colin Stief, the firm specializes in homes "rooted in the spaces and narratives of its clients.” The firm describes its work as one that champions “craft, foreground honest materials, heirloom-quality objects meant to improve with time and enhance everyday life.”

Over on Archinect Jobs, the firm is currently hiring for a Senior Interior Architect to join their Brooklyn team. For candidates interested in applying for a position or anybody interested in learning more about the firm’s output, we have rounded up four renovation projects by General Assembly that exemplify the firm’s ethos.

Key West Vacation Home, Key West, FL

General Assembly redesigned the interior of a 1970s vacation home in Key West, Florida, for a New York-based family. The project balances the home’s clean architectural lines with warmer materials, patterned tiles, and colorful textiles. Influences include the Ernest Hemingway House, 1980s Florida aesthetics, vintage advertising, and the owners’ wood-paneled Chrysler LeBaron. 

Learn more on the Key West Vacation Home's Archinect project page

Catskills Farm, Stone Ridge, NY

For the Catskills Farm project, General Assembly converted an old horse barn into a guest house, retaining elements of the original structure. Warm wood cladding contrasts with clean white walls to create a balanced interior. Patterned concrete tiles define distinct areas: custom terracotta tiles surround the wood-burning stove, while black and white tiles distinguish the bedrooms, which also feature in-floor heating.

Learn more on the Catskills Farm's Archinect project page

Callicoon Stone House, Callicoon, NY

The Callicoon Stone House project saw General Assembly renovate a 19th-century stone house originally built in 1780. The design preserved the original stone structure while reorganizing the interior to improve functionality. Existing window openings were maintained, with two converted into exterior doors to frame key views. New elements, including walls and lighting, were inserted within the original stone shell, creating a clear contrast between old and new.

Learn more on the Callicoon Stone House's Archinect project page

Bleeker Street, New York, NY

General Assembly renovated a 1,200-square-foot apartment on Bleecker Street in Manhattan’s West Village, merging a one-bedroom unit with an adjoining studio. The design draws inspiration from a Cubist painting, using rich materials such as velvet, patinated brass, and dark wood to create a warm, nostalgic atmosphere. Crisp detailing and millwork provide contrast and structure, while heirlooms and artworks, including a drawing by Andy Warhol, add historical depth.

Learn more on Bleeker Street's Archinect project page

Meet Your Next Employer is one of a number of ongoing weekly series showcasing the opportunities available on our industry-leading job board. Our Job Highlights series looks at intriguing and topical employment opportunities currently available on Archinect Jobs, while our weekly roundups curate job opportunities by location, career level, and job description.
